q01.title: Timeline Snapshot
q01.prompt: Before we go deep, give a simple snapshot so we interpret everything in context.

fields.label: How long have you known each other total
How long have you been intentionally dating/seeing each other?
About how often do you see each other right now?

examples: How long have you known each other: 2 years. Dating: 6 months. Seeing each other: weekly.
How long have you known each other: 3 months. Dating: 3 months. Seeing each other: multiple times/week.

q02.title: The Notification Reaction
q02.prompt: When their name pops up on your phone, your first micro-reaction is usually:
examples: Warmth or smile (e.g., I feel immediate happiness when their name pops up).
Anxious or tight (e.g., I worry about what they want or if I'm in trouble).
Neutral or flat (e.g., it doesn't really change my mood much).

q03.title: Post-Date Energy
q03.prompt: After a longer stretch together (a date, an evening, or a day), your energy is usually:
examples: Recharged (e.g., I feel more energetic and lighter after hanging out).
Tired but happy (e.g., it was good, but I need some alone time to recover).
Tired and stressed (e.g., I feel drained or like I worked hard to keep things going).

q04.title: Masking / Filtering
q04.prompt: When you're with them for a long stretch, how much do you feel you have to perform or filter yourself?

options.label: moderate filtering, I'm careful about what I say/do
heavy masking, I feel like I have to be on to be liked

examples: None (e.g., I can be weird, quiet, or loud, and they accept it all).
Light filtering (e.g., I'm mostly myself but hold back slightly on controversial opinions).
Heavy masking (e.g., I feel like I'm playing a character to keep them interested).

q05.title: What's Feeling Good
q05.prompt: Let's start with what's working. This matters.

fields.label: 3 things that feel genuinely good or healthy right now
One moment you felt especially safe, cared for, or understood

examples: Examples: consistently planning dates, feeling safe sharing fears, laughing together easily.
Examples: they respect my boundaries, we have great physical chemistry, they get along with my friends.
Moment: When I was sick last week, they brought me soup and didn't make a big deal of it.

q06.title: Pace Comfort
q06.prompt: Right now, the pace of the relationship feels:

options.label: a little fast for my nervous system

examples: Comfortably paced (e.g., things are moving at a speed that feels right for both of us).
Too fast (e.g., they are talking about marriage and I'm still figuring out if I like them).
Too slow (e.g., it feels stagnant and I want more momentum).

q07.title: Current Status (Reality vs Label)
q07.prompt: If a kind stranger asked What are you two?, the most accurate answer is:

options.label: exploring / getting to know each other
dating intentionally, still open to others
functionally exclusive (not seeing others), but undefined

examples: Exploring (e.g., we are just having fun and getting to know each other).
Functionally exclusive (e.g., we haven't said it, but neither of us is looking elsewhere).
Exclusive (e.g., we have had the talk and are committed).

q08.title: What DTR Means to Me
q08.prompt: If you define the relationship, what does that specifically mean to you? Select all that fit.

options.label: future intent becomes more explicit (where this is going)

examples: Exclusivity (e.g., we agree to close our dating apps and focus only on each other).
Clear label (e.g., I want to call them my boyfriend/girlfriend/partner).
Future intent (e.g., I want to know if we are building toward something long-term).

q09.title: Exclusivity Definition (Operational)
q09.prompt: People mean different things by exclusive. What would exclusivity mean to you right now?

fields.label: Which are part of exclusivity for you?

options.label: transparency about close friendships that could create confusion
agreement on emotional boundaries (what counts as betrayal)

examples: No dating others: We stop seeing other people entirely.
No flirting: We stop entertaining interest from others.
Deleting apps: We remove dating profiles.
Transparency: We tell each other if an ex reaches out.

q10.title: Why This Check-In Now
q10.prompt: What is driving the urge to define things right now? Select any that fit, then rank the ones that matter most.

options.label: desire: I genuinely want to move forward
safety: I need clarity to feel steady
fear: I'm afraid of losing them or being replaced
logic: enough time has passed for a decision point
discomfort: the ambiguity is starting to hurt
pressure: external pressure (friends, family, age, etc.)
spiritual: I feel spiritual clarity or prompting

examples: Desire (e.g., I really like them and want to secure this connection).
Safety (e.g., I need to know where I stand so I can stop feeling anxious).
Logic (e.g., we've been dating 6 months, it's time to decide).
Fear (e.g., I'm terrified they will meet someone else if I don't lock it down).

q11.title: What Should Change After Labeling
q11.prompt: If you define the relationship, what do you believe should change (if anything)?

fields.label: Select any that you expect to change

options.label: nothing major should change, just clarity

examples: Communication consistency: I expect us to talk every day.
Social visibility: I expect to meet their friends soon.
Emotional responsibility: I expect them to care more about my feelings.
Nothing major: We are already acting like a couple, I just want the title.

q12.title: Expectations You're Carrying
q12.prompt: Name the expectations you already have, even if you haven't said them out loud.

fields.label: Which of these feel fair vs possibly unrealistic?

examples: Expectation: That I become their priority on weekends.
Expectation: That they stop talking to their ex.
Expectation: That we start planning a trip together.

q13.title: Communication Expectations
q13.prompt: In an ideally healthy defined relationship, communication consistency would look like:

options.label: steady but simple (a basic daily touchpoint)
consistent and connected (regular check-ins, predictable rhythm)
This avoids redundancy with Phase 1.5 channels by focusing on expectation level, not tooling.

examples: Steady but simple (e.g., a daily check-in text is enough).
Consistent and connected (e.g., regular texting throughout the day and goodnight calls).
Highly integrated (e.g., always knowing where the other person is).

q14.title: Exclusivity Reality Check
examples: Yes (we have explicitly agreed to be exclusive).
No (we are still technically free to see others).
It's complicated (we act exclusive but haven't defined it).

q15.title: Exclusivity Safety and Stability
q15.prompt: If exclusivity is involved (or hoped for), how steady does it feel right now?
examples: Very steady (e.g., their actions match their words completely).
Mostly steady (e.g., usually good, but they sometimes go silent).
Unclear (e.g., I'm constantly guessing if they are still interested).

q16.title: Boundaries and Pace Compatibility
q16.prompt: Right now, do your boundaries and pacing feel compatible?
examples: Aligned: We both want to see each other twice a week.
Mismatched on physical pace: They want to move faster sexually than I do.
Mismatched on emotional pace: I am falling in love, they are still 'seeing how it goes'.

q17.title: Integration Pace
q17.prompt: The pace of integrating lives (friends, family, routines, church/community visibility if applicable) feels:

options.label: a little fast for my nervous system

examples: Healthy (e.g., meeting friends felt natural and fun).
Too fast (e.g., meeting parents after 3 weeks felt like too much pressure).
Too slow (e.g., I feel hidden because I haven't met anyone in their life yet).

q18.title: Daily Operating Systems
q18.prompt: How do your day-to-day rhythms (sleep, cleanliness, pace, planning vs spontaneity, chaos tolerance) fit?
examples: Seamless (e.g., we are both morning people and like a tidy house).
Complementary (e.g., I cook, they clean; I plan, they execute).
Friction (e.g., their messiness stresses me out constantly).

q19.title: The Pink Flag Check (Chemistry Filter)
q19.prompt: Is there something you're minimizing because the chemistry is strong? You can keep it high-level.

fields.label: Are you ignoring a small-but-real concern?

examples: No concern: Everything feels green light.
Yes: Conflict behavior (they shut down and won't talk for days).
Yes: Money habits (they seem financially irresponsible).

q20.title: Emotional Safety
q20.prompt: Do you feel emotionally safe being fully honest with this person?

fields.label: What makes it feel less safe

examples: Yes (e.g., I can share my deepest fears and they listen without judgment).
Mostly (e.g., I share most things, but hide my anxiety to not look 'needy').
No (e.g., I worry they will think less of me if I show weakness).

q21.title: Eggshel ls Check
q21.prompt: Do you feel you have to manage their emotions to keep peace?
examples: No (e.g., I feel free to bring up issues).
Sometimes (e.g., I hesitate to bring up needs because they might get annoyed).
Yes, regularly (e.g., I constantly monitor their mood to avoid conflict).

q22.title: Felt Respect
q22.prompt: Do you feel consistently respected in tone, effort, honesty, and boundaries?
examples: Yes (e.g., they respect my 'no' always).
Mixed (e.g., they are mostly respectful, but sometimes pushy about time).

q23.title: Emotional Regulation Effect
q23.prompt: Overall, this relationship tends to make your nervous system feel:
examples: Regulated (e.g., I feel calm and safe with them).
Open and hopeful (e.g., I feel excited about the future context).
Anxious/activated (e.g., I feel on edge or hyper-vigilant).

q24.title: Conflict Pattern
q24.prompt: When tension shows up, which pattern is most true right now?

options.label: not enough conflict yet to know

examples: We talk and repair (e.g., we can disagree but come back together stronger).
We avoid it (e.g., we pretend nothing happened and just move on).
Escalates (e.g., small disagreements turn into big fights).

q25.title: Repair Reliability
q25.prompt: After a hard moment, you usually feel:
examples: More connected (e.g., resolving it made us feel closer).
About the same (e.g., we got through it).
Less safe (e.g., I'm afraid to bring it up again).

q26.title: Hard Topics Avoidance
q26.prompt: Is there anything you're avoiding because it might change the relationship? You don't need to share details, just the category.
examples: None (e.g., we have discussed everything difficult).
Money (e.g., I haven't asked about their debt yet).
Faith (e.g., I'm worried our religious views are too different).

q27.title: Not-Okay Conflict Behaviors (and what to do)
q27.prompt: Which conflict behaviors are not okay for you, and what should happen if one occurs?

fields.label: If one happens, what should the immediate response be?

examples: Not okay: Yelling, name-calling, stonewalling.
Response: 'I can't continue this conversation while you are yelling. Let's take 20 minutes.'

q28.title: Values Alignment (Real-Life, Not Theory)
q28.prompt: Do your core values feel aligned in real life right now?
examples: Aligned (e.g., we both value family and honesty deeply).
Misaligned (e.g., they prioritize work over everything, I prioritize connection).
Mixed (e.g., we share political views but differ on financial goals).

q29.title: The Hope It Changes Check
q29.prompt: Are you hoping something important will change if you commit?
examples: No (e.g., I accept them exactly as they are today).
Yes (e.g., I hope they become more ambitious/cleaner/more communicative).

q30.title: What You Hope Would Change
q30.prompt: If yes or unsure: what are you hoping will change? (1-3 sentences)
examples: I hope they will start planning dates more often once we are 'official'.
I hope they will be more open about their feelings.

q31.title: Self-Editing Check
examples: More myself (e.g., I feel freer and more authentic with them).
Edited (e.g., I hold back my true personality to fit what they like).

q32.title: The Quiet Dealbreaker
q32.prompt: Is there a potential dealbreaker you're trying not to look at yet? You don't have to name details.
examples: No potential dealbreakers.
Yes: Life direction (they want to be nomadic, I want roots).
Yes: Kids (they are unsure, I definitely want them).

q33.title: What's Driving DTR Urgency
q33.prompt: Which is most true right now?
examples: Grounded desire (e.g., I want this partnership because it adds to my life).
Anxiety (e.g., I'm afraid of being alone or losing them).
Both (e.g., I really like them, but I'm also scared).

q34.title: Your Body's Answer
q34.prompt: When you imagine being officially committed to them, your body feels:
examples: Calm/settled (e.g., a warm feeling in my chest).
Excited/energized (e.g., butterflies and smiles).
Tight/uneasy (e.g., a knot in my stomach).

q35.title: If They Wanted to Wait
q35.prompt: If they said not yet, you would mostly feel:
examples: Understanding (e.g., I'm willing to wait if they need time).
Hurt (e.g., I would feel rejected and sad).
Relief (e.g., honestly, I'm not ready either).

q36.title: Lean Today
q36.prompt: If you had to choose today, you would most want to:

options.label: move toward defining it, but not yet
keep it undefined for a while

examples: Define it now (e.g., I'm ready to commit fully).
Move toward it (e.g., keep dating exclusively but no label yet).
Step back (e.g., I need space to think).

q37.title: Readiness Score (Now)
q37.prompt: On a scale of 1-10, how ready are you to define the relationship?

fields.label: Readiness score (1 = not ready at all, 10 = ready and at peace)

options.label: 10 = ready and at peace doing it now

fields.label: What would raise it by 1-2 points?

examples: 8: I feel very good about us, just want to clarify one boundary.
10: I am completely at peace and excited to define this.
3: I have too many doubts right now.

q38.title: What You Still Need
q38.prompt: What do you still need to decide cleanly? Select any.
examples: More time (e.g., I need a few more weeks to see consistency).
Hard conversation (e.g., we need to talk about finances first).
Meeting family (e.g., I need to see how they are with my siblings).

q39.title: Healthy Yes Requirements
q39.prompt: For a healthy yes, what must be true? (Up to 3 bullet points)
examples: They must be willing to go to therapy if we get stuck.
We must agree on being exclusive.
They must be open about their past relationships.

q40.title: Healthy No / Not Yet Next Step
q40.prompt: If the answer is no or not yet, what would the most respectful next step look like for you?
examples: We should cool things off and see other people.
We should keep dating but check in again in 2 weeks.
We should break up if we aren't on the same page.

q41.title: The Honesty Check
q41.prompt: Is there a part of you that already knows your answer but is afraid to admit it?
examples: No (e.g., I am being totally honest with myself).
Yes (e.g., deep down I know they aren't 'the one', but I don't want to be lonely).

q42.title: Faith Relevance
q42.prompt: How relevant is faith/spiritual life to your relationship decisions?
examples: Central (e.g., my faith guides all my decisions).
Important (e.g., it matters but isn't the only factor).
Not relevant (e.g., I am not religious).

q43.title: Spiritual Integrity
q43.prompt: If faith matters to you: does this relationship support or strain your spiritual integrity right now?
examples: Supports (e.g., we pray together and encourage each other).
Strains (e.g., we argue about how we spend Sundays).

q44.title: Faith-Based Expectations / Standards
q44.prompt: If applicable, which faith-based expectations matter for defining the relationship? Select any.
examples: Shared worship (e.g., going to church together).
Sexual standards (e.g., waiting for marriage).
Tithing (e.g., agreement on charitable giving).

q45.title: Guidance Style Preference
q45.prompt: When receiving guidance (human or AI), you prefer it to be:
examples: Direct and honest (e.g., just tell me the truth).
Gentle and validating (e.g., be kind and supportive).
Structured (e.g., give me a plan).

q46.title: Challenge vs Comfort Dial
q46.prompt: Right now, do you want to be challenged, comforted, or both?
examples: Mostly challenged (e.g., push me to grow).
Mostly comforted (e.g., tell me it's going to be okay).

q47.title: What You Most Want Help With
q47.prompt: What do you most want help seeing clearly right now?
examples: My readiness (e.g., am I seeing this clearly?).
Their signals (e.g., are they really interested?).

q48.title: Privacy Preference for Outputs
q48.prompt: How private do you want your results and recommendations to be?
examples: Just for me (e.g., I want to process this privately).
Shareable summary (e.g., I want something I can show my partner or friend).

lite.title: Lite Check-in
lite.post_timebox_activity: Take a break and do something enjoyable.
